required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pleth Variability Index (PVI) to Predict Fluid Responsiveness
clinical_study.official_title: Validation of PVI as a Parameter to Predict Fluid Responsiveness

brief_summary.textblock: Interventional data collection study to evaluate the ability of pleth variability index (PVI) to predict fluid responsiveness in comparison with other dynamic parameters including pulse pressure variation (PPV) and stroke volume variation (SVV).

detailed_description.textblock: No subjects were enrolled into the validation portion of this study.

primary_outcome.description: Correlation between PVI and SVV to assess PVI as a predictor for fluid responsiveness.

arm_group.description: All subjects are enrolled into this arm and will receive an investigational pulse CO-Oximeter sensor, including nasal sensors, with the same or similar technology and materials as the Masimo FDA cleared devices and sensors.

intervention.description: Investigational Pulse Oximeter Sensor will measure hemoglobin (SpHb), pulse rate (PR), perfusion index (PI), pleth variability index (PVI), oxygen reserve index (ORI), etc.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years of age or older
- Scheduled for elective surgery requiring general anesthesia and mechanical ventilation
- Arterial line and Swan-Ganz catheter placement indicated as part of the scheduled surgical procedure
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with surgeries at or around site of sensor placement or skin abnormalities affecting the sensor placement area such as psoriasis, eczema, angioma, scar tissue, burn, fungal infection, substantial skin breakdown, nail polish, or acrylic nails that would prevent monitoring of pulse-oximeter physiological parameters during the study
- Patients with cardiac arrhythmias
- Patients with intracardiac shunts
